section.title: Pane manipulation
section.para: The main window consists of several panes, the main menu, and a status bar. You can change the position of a pane, or even undock it as a separate window, by clicking and holding its name and dragging it.

note.para: If you cannot see all panes (opened or minimized), you can use the command in the menu to restore them to their default state.

section.para: The top right corner of a pane will show different icons depending on the type of pane and its current status:

row.entry: Minimizes the pane, so that it only shows as a tab at the bottom of the window.
Restores a maximized pane to its previous layout.
Undocks the pane from the main window.
Returns the pane to the main window.

section.para: You can group panes in the same area of the window. Doing so shows a tab with the name of the panes the top of the group. Panes can be resized by dragging the separators between them. Should you lose track of the changes you made to the user interface, you can use the command in the menu any time to go back to the default layout.

section.title: Context menus
section.para: Some panes have a specific associated context menu. You can call that menu using the standard method for your OS, or with the OmegaT defined shortcuts (see for details).

section.title: Dragging and dropping
section.para: Files can be dragged and dropped on certain panes, with the following results.

listitem.para: Editor pane: Dropping an OmegaT project file (omegat.project) onto this pane will open the corresponding project will be opened after closing the currently open project, if any.
Dropping other files will copy them to the source folder. This also applies to the window.
Fuzzy Matches pane: Dropping .tmx files onto this pane will copy them to the tm folder.
Glossary pane: Dropping files with a recognized glossary extension (.txt, .tab, etc.) will copy them to the glossary folder.

section.title: Editor
section.para: This is where you type and edit your translations.
The text is split into numbered segments. You can scroll through the document and double-click on any segment to open and edit it.

listitem.para: The line in bold characters against a green background is the source text to translate.
The line below showing the cursor is where you enter the translation.

That line ends with a segment marker. In this example, (<segment 0400 ¶> is the marker, with 0400 as the number of the segment in the project and a ¶ symbol identifying that segment as the first in a paragraph.
You can make changes to any of the content that comes before the segment marker.
The line below the segment marker is a different segment in the source language that has not been translated yet.

Use or another command that moves to a new segment to:
register the segment in the project translation memory, and
enter the next segment to translate.

section.para: Depending on your editing behavior settings, entering a new segment may leave the line for translation empty, automatically enter the source text, or automatically enter the existing translation in your memory most similar to the segment to translate. See for details.

note.para: You are free to modify the Editor display to suit your workflow.

section.title: Empty translations
section.para: If you leave the translation field empty, OmegaT will treat it as untranslated and keep it in the original language when it creates the translated documents.

OmegaT is can store translations that are identical to the source text. This can be useful for documents that contain trademarks, names or other proper nouns, or sections in a third language that do not require translation. See for details.

section.title: Editor context menu
section.para: The default shortcut key to display the context menu is the Menu key on Windows and Linux, and SEsc on macOS. You can also bring up the menu by right clicking the mouse (C + click on macOS).

The Editor pane context menu offers:
Cut, Copy, Paste functions,
Go To Segment (to jump to the segment under the pointer),
Search Dictionaries (to search for the selected term in an installed dictionary),
Add Glossary Entry (equivalent to ), and other functions available from the menu.
If you have selected text and defined entries in , they will also be displayed in the menu.

section.title: Auto-completion menu
section.para: The default key shortcut to display the auto-completion menu is CSpace on Windows and Linux, and Esc on macOS.
This menu offers the auto-completion options set in .

section.title: Dragging, selecting, and overwriting
section.para: It is possible to drag text from anywhere in the main window and drop it into the active segment. Text dragged from outside the target segment is copied, while text dragged from within the segment is moved.
By default, the cursor is locked into the target text editing field, and the arrow keys cannot be used to move in the source text.
Pressing F2 unlocks the cursor and makes it possible to use the arrow keys to move in the source text (or anywhere else in the editor). This allows you to select text using the keyboard.
The cursor status (locked or unlocked) is shown at the right of the status bar. Use the same key to lock the cursor again.

By default, typing text inserts the new text after the cursor in the typing direction. If you want to overwrite the existing text, use INSERT on Windows and Linux, or F3 on macOS, to switch to overwrite mode.
The writing mode (overwrite or insert) is shown at the right of the status bar. Use the same key to switch back and forth between each mode.

section.title: Fuzzy Matches
section.para: The match viewer shows the most similar segments from your translation memories. This includes both the internal project translation memory you create in real time as you translate the project, and external memories you have imported from previous projects or received from the client or translation agency. See for details.

When you enter a segment, the first fuzzy match (the one with the highest match percentage) is automatically selected. You can press C2, 3, 4, 5 to select a different match. Obviously, this will have no effect if there is no match corresponding to the number pressed.
The selected fuzzy match is highlighted in bold, with words missing from the segment you are translating shown in blue, and adjacent words shown in green.
To use the selected match in your translation, press Cr to replace the target field with the match, or Ci to insert it at the cursor position.

The three different match percentages have the following meaning, in order:
Percentage calculated with stemming based on the source language tokenizer, and ignoring tags and numbers (generally the highest).
Percentage calculated without stemming, and still ignoring tags and numbers (generally slightly lower).
Percentage calculated on the entire text, including tags and numbers (generally the lowest).
You can change how matches are displayed or sorted. See for details.

section.title: Glossary
section.para: The Glossary pane shows the translations of terms in the current segment that are present in the glossary files located in the project's folder.
You can select a term in the glossary pane and right click on it to insert it into the translation.

If you have activated in the menu, you can right click on the highlighted word in the source segment to open a pop-up menu listing the translations available in your glossaries. Selecting one will insert it in the segment at the current cursor position.
You can use the glossary preferences to fine tune how the glossaries are displayed. See for details.
OmegaT includes one writable glossary file per project. Use in the menu to add terms to that file.
Modifications to any glossary file in the glossary folder are immediately recognized by OmegaT and displayed in the glossary pane.

section.title: Dictionary
section.para: Dictionaries refer to the electronic equivalents of the printed dictionaries, such as Merriam-Webster, Duden, or Larousse, that you might have on your desk. See for details.

section.title: Machine Translation
section.para: The machine translation pane, when opened, contains the suggestions produced by machine translation tools for the current segment. Use Cm to replace the translation of the current segment with the suggested translation.
See for details.

section.title: Multiple Translations
section.para: A given source segment may require several different translations, depending on context. If the current translation of the segment is not suitable, you can use the command in the menu to specify an alternative translation. The entered translation will then be treated as an alternative translation of the source segment.
You can define one of the alternatives—the most common or likely, for instance—as the default translation with the command.

section.title: Notes
section.para: You can add notes to the currently active segment. This lets you come back to it later to review the translation, check that alternative translations are correct, or ask colleagues for their opinion, for example. You can browse through the notes using the GoToNext Note and GoToPrevious Note commands.

section.title: Status bar
section.para: The status bar displays workflow information at the bottom of the main window. It provides feedback on the progress of specific operations, and also displays the number of fuzzy and glossary matches for the current segment.
The counters in the lower right corner keep track of the progress of the translation. (The left-hand column uses the numbers from the above figure):

row.entry: Number of segments: translated/total for the current file
Number of unique segments: translated/total for the entire project
Total number of segments in the project (including repetitions)
Number of source and target characters in the current segment

section.para: From a practical standpoint, the second pair of numbers is the most important since it show how much you have done so far with respect to the total number of segments to translate. The project in the example is evidently finished, as all the unique segments have been translated.

You can also click on the counters to switch to a percentage-based indication of your progress. In that case, the first pair of numbers shows you the percentage of the current file that has been completed, with the number of remaining segments for that file given in parentheses. Similarly, the second pair gives you a completion percentage for the entire project, along with the number of total remaining segments in parentheses. In projects with a large number of segments of very different lengths, this can be a more useful indicator of progress than a simple segment count.
